comment._content: I think it is 'Major Lushington' on the far left with the tache. See catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000036301

comment._content: think your right......http://www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1901/Waterford/Waterford_Urban_No__3/Barrack_Street/1764084/           On original it says head of house in Barracks return. Of course it doesnt explain the presence of the maid

comment.author: 56225952@N06
comment._content: This is certainly a most intriguing photograph! The maid/nurse has got a certain knowing 'come hither' look about her and the gentleman in the middle looks very cocky, self assured a bit of a 'cad'. Whichever way you look at it and how you interpret it, it's a fabulous photograph. Thank you for posting it.

comment.author: 55597723@N02
comment._content: Nice Photo & Place. Lovely expressions. Fine looking & lovely People.

comment.author: 59036290@N07
comment._content: Can't explain the central man's ill fitting hair but the 'scholar' bit is because the quoted 1901 census return asks for the person's occupation "before enlistment or appointment".  In the case of Major [Stephen?] Lushington he was most likely a career officer who got his commission straight after education.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: Strange location for a photo and strange pose. All but the Major and the maid are looking away from the camera.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Certainly looks theatrical and I would say the photo was taken at the Artillery Barracks. Major Stephen Lushington is this man I believe, "Stephen Lushington was born in January 1864 and was educated at Eton. Commissioned into the Royal Artillery in February 1884, he was advanced to Captain in January 1893 and to Major in February 1900. In the latter rank he acted as Inspector-General of Police, and as Commandant of Militia, in British Guiana from 1902-07, services that were rewarded by his appointment to C.M.G. in the latter year. The advent of hostilities in August 1914 found Lushington serving as a Lieutenant-Colonel in 41st Brigade R.F.A., which unit he took to France and commanded at Villers-Cotteret on 1 September, when his batteries successfully covered the withdrawal of the 4th Guards Brigade, although ‘under an infernal fire’; 41st Brigade R.F.A. provided similar support to the 2nd Worcestershires at Polygon Wood at the end of the following month. Lushington was mentioned in despatches and created a C.B. (London Gazette 18 February 1915). From 1915 until 1919, he served on the R.A. Staff as a Temporary Brigadier-General and was three more times mentioned in despatches, in addition to being awarded the Italian Military Order of Savoy, 4th class. The General died at Farnham, Surrey in December 1940, aged 76 years." www.dnw.co.uk/medals/auctionarchive/searchcataloguearchiv...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Fantastic, thank you! So he was off to British Guiana within a year of this photo being taken...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
